awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Discovery of the molecular mechanisms underlying microevolution of phenotypic plasticity in a developmental trait
awd_abstract_narration:
When organisms are exposed to environmental differences, like changes in temperature conditions, they can grow into alternative forms that are more adapted to particular environments. This project investigates how a nematode roundworm makes the decision to become a long-lived and stress-resistant form instead of a proliferative form that is stress-sensitive. Currently there is little understanding how these types of decisions are made at the molecular level. High-throughput measurements, genome sequencing, and genetic methods will be used to examine this mystery and lay the groundwork for future projects examining how animal development changes in responses to divergent environmental cues.  Undergraduate and high school student training is an important component of this grant.  High school teachers will develop classroom activities for STEM students in cooperation with the principal investigator and high school students will visit the laboratory to carry out hands on experiments with the worms.

Phenotypic plasticity, or the expression of different phenotypes by the same genotype, drives evolutionary adaptation to shifting environments. Despite numerous well-known examples, little is known about the genetic underpinnings and molecular mechanisms that generate phenotypic plasticity. The goal of this grant is to discover how microevolution of this plasticity occurs using the tractable metazoan system Caenorhabditis elegans. Depending on environmental conditions, these nematodes enter an alternative developmental fate, called dauer, or continue development to reproductive adults. Early larval-stage animals that sense high temperature, low food availability, and high population density initiate the development of the dauer stage. Once conditions improve, dauers re-enter development to become reproductive adults. Much of what is known about dauer comes from the study of a single laboratory strain. Although natural variation in dauer formation has been observed, the molecular mechanisms that lead to phenotypic differences remain unknown. An unbiased approach is needed to discover the genes that underlie natural variation in dauer formation in order to understand how phenotypic plasticity evolves. Species-wide association mapping will be performed using a novel high-throughput assay in order to identify loci that underlie differences in this developmental trait. These loci will be narrowed to candidate genes using well tested experimental and computational techniques and then variants will be validated using genome editing. These approaches will lead to discovery of the number and the sizes of genetic effects, the signatures of selection that occur at those loci, and then define the parts of the dauer network involved in the microevolution of phenotypic plasticity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Phenotypic plasticity, or the expression of different phenotypes by the same genotype, drives evolutionary adaptation to shifting environments. Despite numerous well known examples in plants and animals, little is known about the genetic underpinnings and molecular mechanisms that generate phenotypic plasticity in a species. Our goal was to use natural differences across the Caenorhabditis elegans species to understand how phenotypic plasticity in a phoretic dispersal trait varies at the molecular level. 


For more than 50 years, we have known about the C. elegans dauer plasticity trait where early larval stage animals make a decision based on food availability, temperature, and population density to either continue to proliferate or to enter a long-lived dispersal stage (dauer). Using a single laboratory-adapted strain, numerous laboratories defined the molecular pathways that control this decision, including numerous conserved signaling pathways that are identical with human pathways. These discoveries led to deep understanding of how cells respond to nutrients and decide to divide or not along with how the size of cells is controlled. Although these studies informed fundamental biological pathways shared among all animals, they only addressed one genetic strain within the species. If we want to understand the natural relevance and evolution of a trait, then we must look at differences across a species and use quantitative and population genetics to find the genes and pathways that cause individual differences. 


In this project, we built a high-throughput platform to quantitatively measure dauer formation for hundreds of wild C. elegans strains in many experimental replicates to detect phenotypic differences as small as 5%. We found ample natural differences in dauer formation across a set of wild strains and used those data to map the genes that underlie dauer variation. In our first study, we found a gene that encodes a receptor for a pheromone causes differences in dauer formation across the species. C. elegans releases pheromone to communicate population density. Some strains have two receptors to recognize this pheromone, but others only have one receptor. Those strains with two enter dauer more quickly and robustly than strains with only one. We found that, in natural environments, strains with two receptors are often found in areas where food is scarce. The greater dauer response allows these strains to enter dauer and disperse as soon as food resources become low. By contrast, strains with one receptor can grow to much higher population densities and outcompete strains with two receptors when food resources are plentiful. Adaptation to food availability likely drove the evolution of receptor number in C. elegans. Next, we investigated the pheromone cocktails released by wild C. elegans strains and discovered large differences in the production of pheromones, suggesting that these strains “speak” different languages. These language differences arose from molecular changes in the enzymes that make diverse pheromone structures. 


In this project, we also discovered a fundamental feature of genomes that allows adaptation to the natural environment. We found high levels of genomic differences In an area of the genome that was also correlated with differences in dauer formation. Using long-read and short-read sequencing, we characterized this region and found hundreds of others like it sprinkled all over the genomes of every wild C. elegans strain. We named them hyper-divergent regions (HDRs). Using statistical tests and genome assembly, we found that these regions were enriched for genes that are needed for environmental responses, especially pathogen responses, and they contain thousands of new genes never before seen in C. elegans. The major focus of the laboratory moving forward is the characterization of these new genes and their functions in pathogen responses. New gene annotations and pangenome gene set analyses show that they are pathogen sensing genes along with genes used to combat infections. Interestingly, several other groups have found HDRs in genomes of other nematodes, plants, and even humans. The overarching feature is that HDRs seems to underlie adaptation to environmental differences in all species.


To date, the project produced fifteen peer-reviewed publications. All of the phenotypic and genotypic data on plasticity, gene expression, and metabolomics has been made publicly available. Several high school students, graduate and undergraduate students, and two postdocs were trained in molecular quantitative genetics and population genetics along with evolutionary theory. Citizen scientists, high school students, and several classrooms collected over 200 wild Caenorhabditis isolates that contributed to natural genetic and phenotypic differences across the C. briggsae, C. elegans, and C. tropicalis population-wide resources (CaeNDR).
